turns.content: You are a married couple living in Jerusalem with four children and want to host a purim seuda for your friends. The problem is that you only have space to host 38 people and you want to open the invitation to a larger group of people. Therefore, you will inform them all of the seuda and tell that it is first-come first-served. Everyone will be expected to bring a dish as the meal will be pot-luck style. Please draft a clever and lighthearted invitation asking people to confirm whether they will come. You must include references to rabbinic and biblical sources, double entendres and movies which came out between 2000 and 2008.

Dear friends,

We hope this invitation finds you well. As the saying goes, "Mishenichnas Adar marbin b'simcha" (When Adar begins, we increase in joy). This year, we would like to share that joy with you at our Purim Seuda!

In honor of the holiday, where we celebrate Queen Esther's bravery and the saving of the Jewish people, we are inviting you to come and join us for a potluck feast. Just like Queen Esther, who invited King Ahasuerus and all of the Jews to a feast in Shushan (Esther 5:4), we too would like to open our doors to you.

However, our Jerusalem apartment can only hold 38 guests, so it will be first-come first-served. So, we say to you what King Ahasuerus said to Esther, "If I have found favor in your eyes, come to the dinner I will prepare for you." (Esther 5:4)

In keeping with the festive spirit of the holiday, we ask that each of you bring a dish to share, just like in the movie "My Big Fat Greek Wedding" where the guests bring a dish to the table.

So, let us come together to celebrate the holiday of Purim with food, drink, and merriment. Please let us know if you can join us for this special Seuda by replying "Hineini" (Here I am) to this invitation.

Wishing you all a Happy Purim!

Warm regards,
[Your Names]
Thanks. You now need to re-write it in the form of an annoucement by a medieval town crier

"Hear ye, hear ye! All good people of Jerusalem, come gather round!

'Tis the month of Adar, and the joy it brings, a time for feasting, song and merry makings.

In the spirit of Queen Esther, who saved our Jewish kin, we invite thee to a potluck feast within.

At our humble abode, there's room for just 38, so first-come first-served, we ask that ye be.

Bring a dish to share, just as in days of old, when guests would gather, the table to hold.

Let us come together, to celebrate this night, with food, drink and merriment, till morning's light.

So, if thou art willing, reply with "Hineini", and join us for this Purim Seuda, so fine-y.

'Tis a time for rejoicing, for making merry, so heed our call, and come make history!

This announcement brought to thee, by the town crier."

Re-format this to be written in the form of a talmudic discussion, including through citation of supporting sources. One of the sources that needs to be incorporated is the statement of the Mishna in Avot (5:5) that when the Jews stood it was crowded but when they bowed there was room.

Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai teaches us in Avot (5:5), "Rav Yehuda says in the name of Rav: When the Jews stood at Mount Sinai to receive the Torah, the place was crowded. However, when they bent down in prayer, there was room for all."

In light of this teaching, let us consider the matter of hosting a Purim Seuda.

Rabbi Eliezer says, "Just as Queen Esther invited King Ahasuerus and all the Jews to a feast in Shushan (Esther 5:4), so too should we open our doors to our friends and community during the holiday of Purim."

Rabbi Akiva adds, "And let us not forget the words of King Ahasuerus, who said to Queen Esther, 'If I have found favor in your eyes, come to the dinner I will prepare for you.' (Esther 5:4) We too must extend this invitation to all those who would like to join us in celebrating the holiday."

Rabbi Shimon continues, "However, our abode can only hold 38 guests, just as the Mishna in Avot (5:5) teaches us that when the Jews stood, the place was crowded. Therefore, we must establish a system of first-come, first-served, so that all may partake in the joy of the Purim Seuda."

Rabbi Joshua adds, "And let us also follow the example set by the guests in the movie "My Big Fat Greek Wedding", where each brings a dish to share in the feast."

Therefore, we conclude that hosting a Purim Seuda, in the spirit of Queen Esther and King Ahasuerus, is a worthy endeavor, and we extend an invitation to all who would like to join us. Let us come together to celebrate the holiday with food, drink, and merriment, just as the Mishna in Avot (5:5) teaches us that when we bow in prayer, there is room for all.
Now rewrite it in the form of a limerick

A Purim Seuda we did desire,
With guests and food, to light the fire,
With just enough space,
For the guests to embrace,
We'll feast and drink, like King Ahasuerus dire.

So come one, come all, do not delay,
With food to bring, let's make it play,
First-come, first-served,
So don't be reserved,
Join us, let's celebrate Purim this way!
